MINOS uses the Neutrinos at the Main Injector (NuMI) neutrino beam measured in two locations: at Fermilab, close to beam production, and 735 km downstream, in Northern Minnesota. By observing the oscillatory structure in the neutrino energy spectrum, MINOS can precisely measure the neutrino oscillation parameters in the atmospheric sector. These parameters were determined to be </subfield><subfield code=" ">= 2.74{sub -0.26}{sup +0.44} x 10⁻³ eV²/c⁴ and sin²(2θ₂₃) > 0.87 (68% C.L.) from analysis of the first year of data, corresponding to 1.27 x 10²° POT.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="b">AC02-07CH11359</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="7"><subfield all_text_timv: Neutrino oscillation results from MINOS [electronic resource]. Washington, D.C. : United States. Dept. of Energy, 2007. Oak Ridge, Tenn. : Distributed by the Office of Scientific and Technical Information, U.S. Dept. of Energy. 4 pages : digital, PDF file. text txt rdacontent computer c rdamedia online resource cr rdacarrier Published through SciTech Connect. 08/01/2007. "fermilab-conf-07-175-e" Presented at 30th International Cosmic Ray Conference (ICRC 2007), Merida, Yucatan, Mexico, 3-11 Jul 2007. Sousa, Alexandre. Free-to-read Unrestricted online access star The Main Injector Neutrino Oscillation Search (MINOS) long-baseline experiment has been actively collecting beam data since 2005, having already accumulated 3 x 10²° protons-on-target (POT). MINOS uses the Neutrinos at the Main Injector (NuMI) neutrino beam measured in two locations: at Fermilab, close to beam production, and 735 km downstream, in Northern Minnesota. By observing the oscillatory structure in the neutrino energy spectrum, MINOS can precisely measure the neutrino oscillation parameters in the atmospheric sector. These parameters were determined to be  = 2.74{sub -0.26}{sup +0.44} x 10⁻³ eV²/c⁴ and sin²(2θ₂₃) > 0.87 (68% C.L.) from analysis of the first year of data, corresponding to 1.27 x 10²° POT. notes_summary_ssim: The Main Injector Neutrino Oscillation Search (MINOS) long-baseline experiment has been actively collecting beam data since 2005, having already accumulated 3 x 10²° protons-on-target (POT). MINOS uses the Neutrinos at the Main Injector (NuMI) neutrino beam measured in two locations: at Fermilab, close to beam production, and 735 km downstream, in Northern Minnesota. By observing the oscillatory structure in the neutrino energy spectrum, MINOS can precisely measure the neutrino oscillation parameters in the atmospheric sector.
